metadata.titleEn: A high-resolution inland surface water body dataset for the tundra and boreal forests of North America
metadata.description:
The circumpolar boreal and tundra biomes are the highest concentrations of the global inland water bodies, including lakes, reservoirs, and ephemeral ponds. The majority of these water bodies are small-sized but enormous in number. These small water bodies are essential to global greenhouse gas emissions; however, they are vulnerable to climate change, and little has been known. Thus, it is critical to investigate water bodies in this highly concentrated region, especially the small water bodies. This study presented a comprehensive dataset of water bodies for the tundra and boreal biomes in North America (WBD-NAHL). The 10-m resolution Sentinel-2 and the 30-m resolution JRC water dataset were adopted as the main inputs to enhance the ability on identifying small water bodies (Figure 1). The main contributions of this dataset are as follows: 1) the first investigation of water bodies in the tundra and boreal biomes in North America. Nearly 6.5 million water bodies were identified, about 90% of which were smaller than 0.1 km2; 2) this dataset provides the locations, areas, and morphological attributes for each water body, enabling the analysis of water body distribution, types, and more, which is expected to support studies in the water cycle, carbon emission, and permafrost in high latitudes under global climate change.
Figure 1: Distributions of the percent (a), area (b), perimeter (c), and SI (d), and the number (e) of the water bodies in the North American tundra and boreal forest regions (aggregated to 5 km×5 km grids).
This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 42171140) and the NSFC BSCTPES project (grant no. 41988101)

background: Inland surface waters are abundant in the tundra and boreal forests of North America, essential to environments and human societies but vulnerable to climate changes. These high-latitude water bodies differ greatly in their morphological and topological characteristics related to the formation, type, and vulnerability. Inland surface water occupies only 2 % of the global land surface, but it plays a critical role in terrestrial ecosystems. More than 55 % of global surface waters are located in high latitudes in the Northern Hemisphere, and these northern high-latitude waters are generally small and densely clustered. The high latitudes have warmed faster than other regions, with annual surface temperatures increasing > 1.4 ◦C over the past century. This change in climate is driving changes in terrestrial ecosystems in the Arctic as well. For example, increases in vegetation productivity have been observed across the northern high latitudes. Meanwhile, high-latitude water bodies have started changing since the early 1970s. Permafrost thawing poses a threat to the stability of inland surface waters, especially in arctic lowland surface areas, where most of the water bodies could be thermokarst lakes and have strong interactions with permafrost in the regions. The morphology of the water bodies could be shaped by the surrounding environment. Shoreline complexity affects lake ice formation. Lake connectivity affects fish migration, fish habitats, aquatic assemblages, and water self-purification and accelerates water cycling. The density of water bodies impacts fish density and biomass. The shape and distribution of water bodies reflect what led to the water body formation. Furthermore, information about lake area extent can improve Arctic land surface modeling. In the past, inland surface water was mapped at sub-hectare (i.e., 30 m) resolution using satellite data, and these data provided unprecedented information about the global extent of inland waters, including their spatial distribution and temporal changes. Existing datasets containing information that describe water body shapes, such as the Global Lakes and Wetlands Database (GLWD) and HydroLAKES, are limited to water bodies larger than 0.1 km².
research objective: In this paper, we present a water body dataset for the North American high latitudes (WBD-NAHL). The dataset provides area and morphological attributes for every water body. The WBD-NAHL dataset provides the spatial extent and morphological attributes for each identified water body. It is the first inland water inventory dataset derived at this landscape scale with the capability of delineating inland surface waters as small as 0.001 km².
challenges: The data and methods used to derive the 10 m resolution WBD-NAHL dataset are able to detect water bodies smaller than the 30 m resolution or coarser-resolution satellite-derived datasets but have difficulty identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km². Limit errors in the satellite data provide substantial sources of uncertainty, including an inability to separate rivers and streams because the resolution is too coarse, bias in estimates of water extent resulting from temporal gaps in the data, and misclassifications resulting from spectral resolution. The misclassifications impacted by terrain (e.g., mountain shadows) still exist, even though they have been substantially reduced during data processing.
methods: During this study, we developed an automated approach for detecting surface water extent and identifying water bodies in the 10 m resolution Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data to enhance the capability of delineating small water bodies and their morphological attributes. The approach was applied to the Sentinel-2 data acquired in 2019 to produce the water body dataset for the entire tundra and boreal forests in North America. A machine learning model was trained to retrieve water extent from the Sentinel-2 images from possible water extent restricted by the water probability layer. Permanent water pixels were identified from the resulting water frequency layer as being those pixels with at least 50 % occurrence between June and September. The resulting water pixels were then converted to vector polygons using the “Raster to Polygon” tool in ESRI ArcMap 10.2.
dataset: Nearly 6.5 million water bodies were identified, with approximately 6 million (∼90 %) of them smaller than 0.1 km². The Sentinel-2 multi-spectral images were used to delineate surface water bodies in this study. The dataset provided a more complete representation of the region than existing regional datasets for North America, e.g., Permafrost Region Pond and Lake (PeRL).
findings: The total accuracy of the detected water extent by the WBD-NAHL dataset was 96.36 % through comparison to interpreted data for locations randomly sampled across the region. The WBD-NAHL provided an improved ability on delineating water bodies and reported higher accuracies in the size, number, and perimeter attributes of water body by comparing to PeRL and interpreted regional dataset.

Is it possible to detect water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² using the current data collection techniques?

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are faced in identifying smaller water bodies using satellite-derived datasets?
Concept Completion.Answer: difficulty identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km²

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the high-resolution inland surface water body dataset applied to enhance hydrology research?
Concept Completion.Answer: tundra and boreal forests of North America

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to detect small water bodies in tundra and boreal forests, including any machine learning techniques applied?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to detect small water bodies in tundra and boreal forests involves the development of an automated approach for detecting surface water extent and identifying water bodies using 10 m resolution Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data. A machine learning model was trained to retrieve water extent from the Sentinel-2 images, using a water probability layer to restrict possible water extent.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in deriving high-resolution water body datasets using satellite imagery in high-latitude regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge encountered is the difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² due to the limitations of satellite data resolution. Additionally, there are errors related to temporal gaps in data and misclassifications caused by spectral resolution and terrain factors, such as mountain shadows.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that offers a comprehensive inventory of water bodies in high-latitude regions, focusing on small-scale features?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that offers a comprehensive inventory of water bodies in high-latitude regions is one that identifies nearly 6.5 million water bodies, with about 6 million of them being smaller than 0.1 km². This dataset is based on Sentinel-2 multi-spectral images and provides a more complete representation of the region compared to existing regional datasets.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific challenges involved in using satellite data for detecting small inland water bodies in high-latitude regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: coarse resolution, difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km², bias in water extent estimates from temporal data gaps, misclassifications from spectral resolution, terrain effects like mountain shadows

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features and capabilities of a water body dataset derived from Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data in terms of spatial resolution and morphological attributes?
Feature Specification.Answer: 10 m resolution, delineating inland surface waters as small as 0.001 km², shape index, area, perimeter

Quantification.Question: How many water bodies were identified in the high-resolution dataset for the tundra and boreal forests of North America?

Definition.Question: What is the Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data used for in the context of inland water body detection?
Definition.Answer: The Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data is used to enhance the capability of delineating small water bodies and their morphological attributes by detecting surface water extent and identifying water bodies at a 10 m resolution.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with using satellite-derived datasets for mapping inland surface waters?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km², errors due to coarse resolution impacting the separation of rivers and streams, biases from temporal data gaps, and misclassifications caused by spectral resolution and terrain factors like mountain shadows.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced when mapping inland surface water bodies using 10 m resolution imagery versus coarser-resolution datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Both 10 m resolution and coarser-resolution datasets face challenges such as misclassifications and limited ability to separate narrow features like rivers due to resolution constraints. However, the 10 m resolution datasets can detect smaller water bodies more effectively compared to coarser datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How do automated approaches in satellite data interpretation improve the detection of small inland water bodies in high-latitude regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Automated approaches enhance the capability of delineating small water bodies by using 10 m resolution Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data to identify water extent and morphological attributes. These methods enable the detection of water bodies smaller than those identifiable at 30 m resolution, allowing for a more detailed inventory of small water bodies.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the morphological attributes of inland water bodies contribute to understanding environmental changes in high-latitude regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The shape, size, and distribution of water bodies reflect environmental factors and changes, such as permafrost thawing and climate impacts on the landscape. These morphological attributes provide insights into the formation, type, and vulnerability of water bodies, aiding in the assessment of changes in terrestrial ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² using current satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises from the limit errors in the satellite data, which include an inability to separate rivers and streams due to coarse resolution, biases in estimates of water extent from temporal gaps in the data, and misclassifications from spectral resolution and terrain-induced shadows.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to achieve high accuracy in delineating small water bodies in high-latitude regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges stem from the coarse resolution of previous datasets that restricted the detection capabilities, along with substantial sources of uncertainty such as terrain effects, temporal data gaps, and resolution limitations that impact the ability to separate small features like rivers and streams.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the improved accuracy in detecting water bodies in high-latitude regions using a 10 m resolution dataset?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The improved accuracy is due to the use of a higher resolution (10 m) in the Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data, which enhances the ability to delineate small water bodies and their morphological attributes, along with the application of machine learning models to accurately retrieve water extent.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using machine learning models for detecting surface water extent in high-resolution satellite imagery?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using machine learning models for detecting surface water extent in high-resolution satellite imagery can enhance the capability of delineating small water bodies and their morphological attributes. However, challenges such as difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² and errors due to spectral resolution and terrain misclassifications may still arise.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of mapping inland surface waters at a fine resolution for understanding climate change impacts in high-latitude regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Mapping inland surface waters at a fine resolution allows for a more detailed understanding of climate change impacts by identifying small, densely clustered water bodies that are vulnerable to changes like permafrost thawing. This can provide insights into terrestrial ecosystem changes, such as vegetation productivity and alterations in water body morphology, which are crucial for modeling and predicting future climatic effects.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a dataset that can delineate inland surface waters as small as 0.001 km² in the high latitudes of North America?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a dataset that can delineate inland surface waters as small as 0.001 km² is important because it provides a more detailed and comprehensive inventory of water bodies, which are critical to terrestrial ecosystems. These small and densely clustered northern high-latitude waters play a significant role in hydrology, matter, and energy cycles, and their detailed mapping can improve Arctic land surface modeling.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of using Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data and machine learning techniques in identifying water bodies in tundra and boreal forests?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of using Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data and machine learning techniques are to enhance the capability of delineating small water bodies and accurately capture their morphological attributes. These techniques aim to overcome limitations of coarser-resolution datasets and provide a more complete representation of the water bodies in tundra and boreal forests.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of addressing challenges like misclassifications and resolution limitations in satellite-derived water body datasets for high-latitude regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing challenges such as misclassifications and resolution limitations in satellite-derived water body datasets is intended to provide more accurate and reliable data on the extent and morphology of water bodies. This improves the understanding of their ecological roles, interactions with permafrost, and responses to climate changes, ultimately supporting better environmental management and research in high-latitude regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data to detect and classify inland surface water bodies in tundra and boreal forests?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An automated approach was developed to detect surface water extent and identify water bodies using 10 m resolution Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data. The machine learning model was trained to retrieve water extent from the images, and permanent water pixels were identified from the water frequency layer with at least 50% occurrence between June and September. These water pixels were then converted to vector polygons using the 'Raster to Polygon' tool in ESRI ArcMap 10.2.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can random forest methods be applied to improve the accuracy of water body extent detection in high-latitude regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Random forest methods were used alongside water indices to detect water. The water index extracted the loose water extent, while random forest methods extracted a more accurate water extent. This approach helped achieve an overall accuracy of 98% in the dataset for high-latitude regions.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the identification of small water bodies in high-resolution satellite imagery?
Enablement.Answer: An automated approach for detecting surface water extent and identifying water bodies in 10 m resolution Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data enhances the capability of delineating small water bodies and their morphological attributes.

Enablement.Question: How do machine learning models enhance the accuracy of water body detection in remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: A machine learning model trained to retrieve water extent from Sentinel-2 images using a water probability layer enhances accuracy by ensuring pixels with at least 50% occurrence between June and September are identified as permanent water pixels.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in remote sensing data collection affect the classification of inland water bodies?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include limit errors in satellite data, difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km², inability to separate rivers and streams due to coarse resolution, and misclassifications from spectral resolution and terrain, such as mountain shadows.

Expectation.Question: Why might some data collection methods encounter difficulties in detecting water bodies smaller than 0.001 km²?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection methods may struggle to identify water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² due to limit errors in satellite data, such as the coarse resolution that makes it challenging to separate small water bodies like rivers and streams, bias from temporal gaps in data, and misclassifications impacted by spectral resolution and terrain features like mountain shadows.

Expectation.Question: Why might the accuracy of water body detection be a concern when using satellite-derived datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Accuracy concerns in water body detection using satellite-derived datasets arise from potential misclassifications due to spectral resolution limitations, terrain influences like mountain shadows, and the inability to accurately detect very small water bodies below a certain size threshold, impacting the precision of water extent estimates.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations and challenges of using satellite-derived datasets for identifying small water bodies in high-latitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Limitations include difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km² due to resolution constraints, inability to separate rivers and streams because the resolution is too coarse, and misclassifications resulting from spectral resolution and terrain influences such as mountain shadows.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the key factors that influence the morphological attributes of water bodies in tundra and boreal forest regions, and how might these be accurately captured in future datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Key factors influencing morphological attributes include the surrounding environment, shoreline complexity, and lake connectivity, which affect ice formation, aquatic habitats, and water cycling. Future datasets could improve accuracy by incorporating higher-resolution data and better addressing environmental interactions affecting water body morphology.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods can accurately detect such small water bodies in tundra and boreal forest areas.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection method used an automated approach with Sentinel-2 multispectral satellite data at a 10 m resolution, along with a machine learning model trained to retrieve water extent, enhancing capability to delineate small water bodies and their morphological attributes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in using satellite-derived datasets for detecting small water bodies in tundra and boreal forest regions and suggest improvements to existing methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include difficulty in identifying water bodies smaller than 0.001 km², limit errors in satellite data, inability to separate rivers and streams due to coarse resolution, bias in water extent estimates from temporal gaps, and misclassifications from spectral resolution and terrain impacts like mountain shadows. Improvements could involve enhancing the resolution of satellite data, increasing temporal frequency of data collection, and refining machine learning models to better handle misclassifications and differentiate between rivers and water bodies.
